results.title: Feeling yes, feeling no: the adult film
results.creator_credit: Moira Simpson, Jennifer Torrance and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: Provides information on how to facilitate a networking workshop for the “Feeling Yes, feeling No” program which provides information on the nature and scope of child sexual assault, the behavioural signs of the sexually assaulted child and the skills necessary to assist a sexual assault victim. Demonstrates the purpose and content of the children’s films and lessons and provides parents and professionals with materials and ideas to reinforce the sexual assault prevention skills the children are taught.

results.title: Feeling yes, feeling no. Parts 1, 2 and 3
results.creator_credit: Moira Simpson, John Taylor, Jennifer Torrance and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: Feeling Yes, Feeling No Parts 1, 2 and 3 are part of a sexual - assault - prevention program for young children. The purpose of this video is to give children the skills necessary to protect themselves from sexual assault - from strangers, from family members, from other trusted persons. Part 1 teaches children basic skills that build self-worth, self-confidence and good judgment. Part 2 reinforces the understanding of “Yes” feelings and “No” feelings and introduces skills to keep children assess potentially dangerous situations involving strangers. Part 3, introduces the issue of sexual assault by a trusted adult.

results.title: Feeling safe staying safe
results.creator_credit: Phil Read, Paul Worthington, South Australian Film Corporation and South Australia. Dept. for Education and Children's Services
results.brief_description: Presents 16 vignettes showing children in a variety of unsafe predicaments, ranging from everyday personal safety situations through to harassment and abuse situations. Each vignette has been designed for use as a single scenario to present to students as part of the problem-solving process and includes students from a variety of cultural and socio-economic backgrounds, from preschool to high school age and with gender as a factor of analysis. Includes support booklet for teacher use. Suitable for primary and secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Phil Read, Paul Worthington, South Australian Film Corporation and South Australia. Dept. for Education and Children’s Services

results.title: Feeling good about yourself
results.creator_credit: Alan Shulman and Feeling Good Associates
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the “yes-no” process - a dynamic method of assertiveness training - with a group of intellectually handicapped people. Shows participants in a workshop going through discussion sessions and experiential exercises exploring issues such as victimisation, making oneself understood, self-esteem, personal strength and sex education. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.
results.description: Demonstrates the “yes-no” process - a dynamic method of assertiveness training - with a group of intellectually handicapped people. results.title: Feel like going home
results.creator_credit: Martin Scorsese, Alex Gibney, Margaret Bodde, Reverse Angle International and Vulcan (US)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Blues Collection = Martin Scorsese presents The Blues a musical journey [DVD]”.
Part of Martin Scorsese’s “The Blues Collection”, “Feel like going home” is Scorsese’s own directorial contribution, tracing the blues from the Mississippi Delta back to its roots in the Niger River, Mali. Musician Corey Harris acts as a guide along the journey, conducting interviews with a variety of musicians and engaging in song with several. Whilst examining the musical milieu of the Mississippi Delta, Scorsese addresses the work of Alan Lomax, the pioneering musicologist who recorded innumerable obscure American musicians and singers. Presents brilliant vintage footage of early blues men, such as Son House and John Lee Hooker whilst painting a picture of the rural poverty that dominated the lives of these future greats. Original performances include Willie King, Corey Harris, Taj Mahal, Keb Mo, Otha Turner, Habib Koite, Salif Keita, and Ali Farke Toure.
